repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Environmental Conservation and
            Rehabilitation (CVRD) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            unsatisfactory, though sustainability is likely, and modest
            institutional development impacts were achieved. Key lessons
            convey that common development objectives between the Bank,
            and Borrower are critical to pursue project implementation,
            and, that the Bank should ensure the appropriate
            implementation arrangements, particularly with implementing
            agencies. Specifically, in light of active participation of
            agencies (other than the Implementing Agency) separate
            Project Agreements, or comparable arrangements could
            authorize the Bank - should default occur - to suspend
            disbursements in the absence of compliance. Indeed, direct
            contractual agreements should be pursued with those entities
            that have the mandate to fulfill the requirements needed to
            meet the project's objective, and, the scope of these
            objectives must not be broader than the scope of the
            Borrower's operational capacity. Lack of clear leverage
            by the Bank, precluded the adherence of the implementing
            agency to both the implementation plan, and agreements
            (partly also because of the Borrower's financial
            capacity to undertake such a program on its own). Such being
            the case, the Bank should seek to expand the stake in the
            fulfillment of agreed actions, by including communities to
            form a wider range of stakeholders, who would then be
            empowered, and, responsible to sustain resources productively.

18225809.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Urban development,Social dev/gender/inclusion

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Environmental Conservation and
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Environmental Conservation and
            Rehabilitation Project has three major objectives: a) to
            support the entire environmental program of Companhia Vale
            do Rio Doce (CVRD) by financing high-priority investments
            throughout its operations; b) to bring about changes in
            CVRD's policies, systems and procedures needed to
            reinforce sound environmental policies and management; and
            c) to correct some of the negative indirect environmental
            and social impact of CVRD's operations in sensitive
            portions of its area of influence, in particular in the
            Carajas corridor. The project consists of the following
            components: 1) air, water and soil pollution control and
            land reclamation investments in CVRD's mining,
            industrial, rail and port operations; 2) natural resource
            investments, which include reforestation and the
            conservation of natural forest and ecosystems in or around
            CVRD's installations; and fauna and flora inventories
            and conservation; 3) socially oriented investments
            contributing to the alleviation of social problems in
            ecologically sensitive areas in CVRD's area of
            influence; 4) studies, research, training, and technical
            assistance, including a comprehensive impact assessment of
            the Tubarao industrial port, other pollution monitoring and
            impact studies; 5) implementation of a comprehensive
            corporate environmental information, control, monitoring and
            auditing system; and 6) other sub-projects and studies,
            aimed at further reducing pollution and environmental degradation.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Environmental Conservation and
            Rehabilitation Project - summary of environmental analysis

abstracts.cdata!:
This report is a summary of the
            environmental analysis of the environmental conservation and
            rehabilitation project in Brazil.  The components of this
            project  are: 1) air, water and soil pollution control and
            land reclamation investments in CVRD's mining,
            industrial, rail and port operations throughout the country;
            2) natural resource investments (reforestation, conservation
            of natural forest and ecosystems and fauna and flora
            inventories and conservation); 3) socially oriented
            investments (municipal improvements and the Amerindian
            program); 4) studies, research, training, and technical
            assistance; 5) implementation of a comprehensive corporate
            environmental information, control, monitoring and auditing
            system; 6) erosion control in mines and along the railroad;
            and 7) environmental impact assessments in the project
            's areas of influence.  The project  will have a
            positive impact on the environment and especially on the
            many indigenous peoples who live in the region. Most
            directly affected by the project are: 1) the Xikrin of
            Catete, whose reservation borders directly on the CVRD
            mining concession; 2) the Gaviao of Mae Maria, whose
            reservation is crossed by the railway line; 3) the Gaujajara
            of Pindare and Caru, whose reservations lie very near the
            railway; and 4) the Awa, who will be provided with
            protection and medical care.  The project  will
            substantially improve the conditions of indigenous
            communities, particularly in terms of health care and land
            demarcation.  Future support for tribal communities should
            concentrate on the demarcation and protection of reserves,
            the provision of health services, and educational campaigns
            designed to prepare tribal communities to better manage,
            protect and develop the natural and other resources
            available to them for their own benefit.  The project should
            also: 1) progressively reduce dependence on its actions and
            funding, by promoting self reliance and community
            participation; 2) remove itself from involvement in day to
            day management of the program by acting through other
            institutions/organizations; 3) finance actions which have
            been designed with the active involvement and support of the
            community; and 4) emphasize actions which will eventually
            lead to self sufficiency and which incorporate ways to
            achieve self management and financial self sufficiency in
            their design.

Brazil - Environmental Conservation and
            Rehabilitation Project - summary of environmental analysis
